clinical_study.brief_title: Methadone for Emergence Delirium in Children Undergoing Outpatient Strabismus Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Methadone for Emergence Delirium in Children Undergoing Outpatient Strabismus Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: Strabismus surgery for children is a very common procedure, with a high incidence of emergence delirium in the recovery room. Pain is often implicated in delirium. The primary aim of this study is to determine whether a single, intraoperative dose of methadone for outpatient ambulatory pediatric strabismus surgery reduces postoperative delirium.

primary_outcome.measure: Pediatric Anesthesia Emergence Delirium scale scores
primary_outcome.time_frame: measured every 10 minutes in the recovery room, until patient is discharged, up to 6 hours.
primary_outcome.description: A low total score would indicate less emergence delirium

secondary_outcome.measure: wong-baker or numeric pain scores, depending on age
secondary_outcome.time_frame: measured every 10 minutes in the recovery room, until patient is discharged, up to 6 hours.
secondary_outcome.description: A low total score would indicate less pain
time the patient is actually discharged from recovery room

arm_group.description: pediatric patients undergoing outpatient strabismus surgery, and receiving methadone
pediatric patients undergoing outpatient strabismus surgery, and not receiving methadone

study_pop.textblock: Healthy children, aged 0-18 years, undergoing outpatient strabismus surgery under general anesthesia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ASA I/II children undergoing outpatient strabismus surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- anything not meeting the above
